articles.title: A Dire New Climate Forecast Is Out. These Are Our Key Takeaways
articles.author: Jenn Jordan
articles.summary: It's been 10 years since the Paris Climate Agreement was signed. The world is on track for a staggering 2.6°C of warming by the end of the century, well above the 1.5°C (2.7°F) target agreed upon in Paris. Some progress has been made in the decade since Paris. However, the gains have not been enough to offset continuing fossil fuel use.

articles.title: Philippines ranks among countries most affected by climate-related disasters
articles.summary: The Philippines suffered 371 extreme weather events between 1995 and 2024, resulting in more than 27,500 deaths and over USD35 billion in economic losses. Globally, there were over 9,700 such events, causing 832,000 fatalities and USD4.5 trillion in damages over the same period.

articles.title: Emissions Reduction grim future ahead
articles.author: Dhurjati Mukherjee
articles.summary: The level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere touched an all-time high in 2024, setting the ground for Earth's warming to aggravate further. India reported the highest absolute increase in emissions with an addition of 165 million tonnes of greenhouse gas during 2023-24, followed by China, Russia, Indonesia and the US.

articles.title: Why the chemtrail conspiracy theory lingers and grows – and why Tucker Carlson is talking about it
articles.author: Calum Lister Matheson
articles.summary: Some people believe that contrails left by aircraft are actually chemtrails, clouds of chemical or biological agents dumped on the unsuspecting public for nefarious purposes, such as weather control or mass poisoning, as some conspiracy theorists say.   .

articles.title: Satellites play critical role in tracking climate adaptation, researchers say
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Satellite-based Earth observation provides a unique tool in tracking climate adaptation. It supports the Paris Agreement's Global Goal on Adaptation. It also gives policymakers tools to measure progress and identify regions at risk. The research was carried out at the University of Galway's Ryan Institute.

articles.title: Ubuntu at the G20 Summit
articles.author: Wanjira Mathai
articles.summary: In one week, South Africa will host the G20 Summit in Johannesburg under the theme 'Solidarity, Equality, Sustainability'. The G20 represents 85% of global GDP, 75% of world trade and two-thirds of humanity. Research shows that a 1°C rise in temperature could slash global GDP by more than 20% in the long run. South Africa has pledged to lead in the spirit of ubuntu.

articles.title: Global Emissions Rise 2.3% In 2024 India Records Highest Absolute Increase: UNEP Report
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Global greenhouse gas emissions rose by 2.3% in 2024, reaching a record 57.7 gigatons of CO2 equivalent, according to the United Nations' report. KNN India reports that global GHG emissions reached a record high in 2024.

articles.title: Alaska advocates for climate-vulnerable villages call for action in wake of devastating storm
articles.author: Alaska Public Media
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong caused devastation in Western Alaska. According to Northern Journal, the cost of protecting infrastructure in Alaska's threatened communities is estimated at $4.3 billion over the next half-century. A 200-page report by the Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium recommended $80 million a year to address the environmental threats to Alaska villages.

articles.title: Under climate assault
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: Pakistan is ranked 15th among the countries most affected by extreme weather events over the past three decades. Pakistan contributes less than 1% of global greenhouse gas emissions. The ten most affected nations are all from the Global South and none from the high-income group. Pakistan alone has faced economic losses exceeding $30 billion from recent floods.

articles.title: Why hosepipe bans across Britain could continue into the winter
articles.author: Maryam Zakir-Hussain
articles.summary: Eight million people remain under hosepipe bans in areas including Yorkshire, Thames Valley, Sussex and Kent due to low reservoir levels. The prolonged dry spell follows the driest spring in 132 years and the hottest summer on record. Water minister Emma Hardy highlighted the ongoing risks to public water supplies, farming, and the environment.

articles.title: Earth likely to ‘overshoot' warming limit, climate experts say
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Scientists warn of irreversible tipping points, from coral die-offs to Amazon drying. U.N. officials stress temperatures can still be brought back down after overshoot. Carbon removal technologies and major emissions cuts are key to reversing warming. The Paris Agreement sought to limit warming to 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit since preindustrial times. Last year it exceeded 1.5 degrees Fahrenheit.

articles.title: Global emissions peak again – but dozens of nations are cutting carbon
articles.author: New Atlas
articles.summary: The world's carbon emissions are on track to hit an all-time high this year. With CO2 emissions still increasing, keeping global warming below 1.5°C is no longer plausible, according to this year's climate report from the UNFCCC.

articles.title: New Ice Age? I Still Have My Global Warming Decorations Up
articles.author: Robert Spencer
articles.summary: There's a conference on global warming in Brazil, but only 53 countries are attending, down from 80 last year. It's a decades-old climate hoax, but it's still getting massive amounts of funding from governments all over the world. The doomsayers know that the public has a short attention span, and the establishment media has no interest in pointing out failed prophecies of doom.

articles.title: Red Deer region sets record high temperature for a Nov. 13
articles.author: Red Deer Advocate Staff
articles.summary: Temperatures reached 16.8 C in the Red Deer region on Thursday, Nov. 13. The previous high was 15 C, recorded in 1946. Seven other locations in Alberta recorded record high temperatures on the same day.       .

articles.title: Fisheries to vote on proposed blue crab harvest rules
articles.author: Jennifer Allen
articles.summary: The Coastal Counties Fisheries Coalition opposes more restrictions on the commercial harvest of blue crabs ahead of the Marine Fisheries Commission's November 19-20 meeting in Wrightsville Beach. The coalition is made up of elected officials from Beaufort, Brunswick, Carteret, Camden, Chowan, Craven, Currituck, Dare, Hertford, Hyde, Onslow, Pasquotank, Perquimans, Tyrrell and Washington counties.

articles.title: When climate crisis meets corruption
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Bangladesh is among the world's most climate-vulnerable nations. In the past year alone, districts such as Feni, Noakhali, Lakshmipur and parts of Cumilla were inundated by severe flooding. The country ranked seventh in the 2020 Global Climate Risk Index and ninth in the 2023 World Risk Index for disaster risk. Transparency International Bangladesh (TIB) reported that more than US$248 million of Bangladesh's climate funds were lost to corruption.

articles.title: In hurricane-torn Jamaica, this couple's climate-resilient breadfruit program offers food and hope
articles.author: Adriana Perez
articles.summary: Mary and Mike McLaughlin planted 250,000 breadfruit trees across the Caribbean and Africa. They want to expand its use as a crop in locations vulnerable to extreme weather events that are intensifying because of human-made climate change. Hurricane Melissa hit Jamaica in the southwestern parish of St. Elizabeth, which has fertile soil favorable to many crops that feed the country.

articles.title: Billions lost, millions affected by #UwanPH
articles.author: Vincent John Abordo
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Uwan left billions in damages, millions of Filipinos affected, and over a thousand hectares of crops destroyed with no chance of recovery. The storm displaced more than 863,000 people, with over 624,000 staying in evacuation centers. The typhoon affected 16 regions, 71 provinces, 865 cities and municipalities, and 12,930 barangays. It made landfall in Dinalungan, Aurora at 9:10 p.m. on November 9. The President declared a one-year period of national state of calamity.

articles.title: COP30: Witness 30 Years of China's Green Efforts
articles.summary: The first United Nations Climate Change Conference was held in Berlin 30 years ago. China's emphasis on environmental protection has continued to increase in recent years. China is a major player in the global economy and has a growing concern about climate change and environmental protection issues.

articles.title: Climate leaders in Brazil talk about ‘overshoot' into warming danger zone
articles.summary: The 2015 Paris Agreement sought to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius since preindustrial times. Last year, Earth warmed by 1.3 degrees Celsius. The limit is based on temperatures averaged over a decade. The UN's annual climate conference is taking place in the Brazilian Amazon city of Belem.

articles.title: Bow Island and other areas in Alberta set a new temperature record
articles.author: Jett Schwaier
articles.summary: Bow Island area in Alberta set a new daily maximum temperature record of 20.2°C, breaking the 2001 record of 19.7°C. Other areas with new records include: Claresholm area: 20.0°C and Coronation area: 17.3 °C. Red Deer area: 16.8°C broke the 1946 record of 15.0 °C and Drumheller area: 19.1 °C broke 2023 record.

articles.title: Red Deer area sets unofficial temperature record for November 13
articles.author: Sheldon Spackman
articles.summary: The Red Deer area reached a daytime high of 16.8 degrees Celsius on Thursday, setting a new record for November 13. The old record high of 15.0 degrees Celsius was set in 1946. The temperature records in this area have been kept since 1904.

articles.title: How climate cooperation turned into a global race for green power
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: The world is emitting more greenhouse gases than ever. Global emissions reached a record 53 billion tonnes in 2024. This is 10% higher than in 2015, when the Paris agreement was signed.    i.shutterstock Piyaset / shutterstock

articles.title: Four flood warnings issued for county as river levels rise- here's where
articles.author: Hereford Times
articles.summary: There are three further flood warnings in place across the county. More flooding is expected as river levels rise, as predicted by the forecasters. The warnings are in place until the end of the day at the earliest. The weather is expected to be very wet.

articles.title: Four flood warnings issued for county as river levels rise- here's where
articles.author: Hereford Times
articles.summary: There are three more flood warnings for the county as river levels rise, and further flooding is expected as a result of the rising water levels. Here's where to go if you're in need of help with flood-related matters.

articles.title: Biggest great white shark ever recorded surfaces off New Jersey
articles.author: Black Hills Pioneer
articles.summary: As water temperatures drop in the North Atlantic, great white sharks migrate south annually for warmth as the sea water gets colder.    -   for warm weather.  for cold weather. For cold weather, for warm water, for warmth, for great whites.

articles.title: Int'l Energy Agency alters forecast: If we stick to the current climate trajectory we're gonna fry
articles.author: Meteor Blades
articles.summary: The world is on track for 2.6 degrees Celsius of warming, according to the International Energy Agency's World Energy Outlook 2025 report released Wednesday. Polls show that despite what's happening with the climate right this minute, only a small fraction of Americans include climate as a top priority for action. The IEA projects that global greenhouse-gas emissions will continue rising through 2050 under current policies.

articles.title: La Grange Differs With Trump 'Hoax' Claim
articles.author: David Giuliani
articles.summary: La Grange Village President Mark Kuchler opposed the Trump administration's proposal to repeal a 16-year-old rule to control greenhouse emissions. In 2009, the EPA determined that greenhouse gases endangered human health and welfare. In September, Trump told the United Nations that climate change is a hoax.

articles.title: Science-backed project maps threats to La Union mangroves
articles.author: The Philippine Star
articles.summary: La Union's mangrove ecosystem is under pressure from coastal development, especially in La Union's coastal areas. The area is home to the La Union Mangrove Project.    .   for more information, go to: http://www.launionmangroveproject.org/

articles.title: La Niña won't impact winter conditions the same way across the US. What to expect in Ohio
articles.author: Bebe Hodges
articles.summary: La Niña will be the main driver of winter weather in the United States. La Niña is a part of a natural climate cycle known as El Niño-Southern Oscillation. It is marked by cooler-than-average ocean water in the Pacific Ocean. Most of Ohio may experience more precipitation than usual this winter.

articles.title: Sustainable Switch: Iceland warns melting glaciers a national security threat
articles.author: Sharon Kits Kimathi
articles.summary: Iceland has declared a climate-related issue as a national security risk. The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) system could collapse, which could destabilize rainfall patterns relied upon by subsistence farmers across Africa, India and South America. Indigenous peoples have no real voice in the negotiations at COP30. California Governor Gavin Newsom lambasted President Donald Trump's decision to reverse the federal government's course on climate action.

articles.title: Residents in massive slum grapple with worsening crisis: 'I am afraid'
articles.author: Hannah Slusher
articles.summary: In Kawangware, one of the largest informal settlements in Nairobi, Kenya, residents are facing worsening droughts and floods. Roughly 60% of the city's population lives in such settlements, squeezed into just 6% of its land. Around 1.1 billion people live in similar conditions around the world. The informal settlements contribute the least to global carbon pollution.

articles.title: Winter strikes Karnataka's Kalaburgi, children gather around fire for warmth
articles.author: ANI
articles.summary: The maximum temperature in Kalaburgi was recorded at 31°C, while the minimum temperature dropped to 1.2°C as of 8:30 am on Saturday. The weather is expected to remain partially cloudy, with cold conditions continuing to prevail. In Tamil Nadu, the authorities issued a weather warning for the coastal district of Thoothukutti, advising fishermen to avoid venturing into the sea until further notice.

articles.title: The Inevitable Climate Overshoot: Navigating a Warming World
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Earth's temperature may temporarily surpass the 1.5°C cap outlined in the Paris Agreement. The UN continues to hold the target as essential. Scientists predict the breach could happen as soon as 2030, peaking at 1.7°C and only returning to safer levels by the 2060s.

articles.title: AfDF Grants $9.48M to Boost Climate Resilience in Sahel Wetland Ecosystems
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Board of Directors of the African Development Fund has approved a $9.48 million grant to launch the Community and Ecosystem Resilience and Adaptation in the Wetlands of the Sahel Catchment Basins Project. The project is financed through the Climate Action Window, the AfDF's dedicated mechanism for supporting climate adaptation in low-income African countries. The Sahel's river catchments have experienced accelerated degradation driven by drought, erratic rainfall, loss of vegetation cover, and unsustainable exploitation practices. Wetlands are vital sources of water, biodiversity, and food security.

articles.title: Winter Finch Irruptions
articles.author: Robert Culbert
articles.summary: The Finch Research Network predicts when winter finches will migrate southward from the boreal forests of northern Canada. They predict that the following species may migrate south in heavier numbers than usual: purple finches, pine siskins, red-breasted nuthatches, evening grosbeaks, redpolls and red crossbills. The most surprising find this week is a cackling goose.

articles.title: IDB, CAF and CDB Launch Debt-for-Resilience Plan for Caribbean At COP30
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), CAF–Development Bank of Latin America and the Caribbean (CAF–CDB) and Caribbean Development Bank have launched a joint initiative aimed at strengthening climate resilience in one of the world's most vulnerable regions. Small island states shoulder some of the highest disaster-related economic losses relative to GDP. Debt-for-resilience swaps convert existing debt service obligations into investments in climate resilience.

articles.title: China donates $85k for Hurricane Melissa relief
articles.summary: After Hurricane Melissa, China has donated US$84,665 under the China-Caribbean Disaster Prevention and Mitigation Fund to The Bahamas. China has been a consistent supporter of Bahamian disaster-readiness efforts over the past three years. After Hurricane Dorian, emergency supplies arrived at the National Emergency Management Agency's relief centre, escorted by the then Chinese Ambassador.

articles.title: Climate leaders are talking about 'overshoot' into warming danger zone. Here's what it means
articles.author: Seattle PI
articles.summary: After years of pushing the world to limit Earth's warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, climate leaders are starting to acknowledge that the target set by the 2015 Paris Agreement will almost surely be breached. They are not conceding defeat, however, and they are not giving up.

articles.title: Are European cities prepared for climate change?
articles.author: Inês Trindade Pereira
articles.summary: 80% of European cities have developed or are developing an emergency response plan related to climate. 78% have an early warning system to notify residents of climate threats. 81% of cities have building regulations for new developments focused on resilience. Municipal revenue (87%) and EU funding (83%) are the most accessed sources of traditional financing for adaptation in cities.

articles.title: #HaveItBothWays: The Antarctic Peninsula
articles.author: John Robson
articles.summary: The Antarctic Peninsula (AP) has been experiencing significant cooling over the past 20 years. With climate change you get to #HaveItBothWays, as we present you with evidence that the AP has been significantly cooler.    .  .

articles.title: The Daily Bucket: Rhino at the Pier
articles.author: Browns Bay
articles.summary: Bird activity is ramping up as migrating seabirds begin showing up to overwinter in Puget Sound. Edmonds, Washington is in the southwestern corner of Snohomish County, about 17 miles north of Seattle. The main subject of this Bucket is the Rhinoceros Auklet, which is regularly seen here in winter along with other wintering birds.

articles.title: Climate goals flounder in headwind from militarization, competition, AI
articles.author: Mada Masr
articles.summary: COP30 kicked off in Belem, Brazil earlier this week. Delegates from 200 countries are attending. The planet is on course for a 2.6 degree temperature rise. We are not on track with the 2015 Paris Agreement goal to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees. We need to reduce our emissions by 45 percent by 2030. Global North is not fulfilling its obligations to implement proper adaptation. Global South needs more climate finance.

articles.title: Billy V's HNN Sunrise surf and weather report for Nov. 14, 2025
articles.summary: There may be an increasing focus of enhanced moisture on the South Hilo and Puna Districts as the day progresses, especially in the morning.       in Puna and in Hilo, there may also be an increase in the humidity.

articles.title: Birds will get sick if you leave out one common ingredient
articles.author: Vita Molyneux
articles.summary: Sean McMenemy, founder of Ark Wildlife shares his advice on what food can be harmful for birds. In the colder months, natural food sources for birds become scarce, so people leave food out for them in the form of bread, leftover scraps, or rice, but they don't give birds the nutrients they need.

articles.title: The Terrible Price of the Climate Change Scam
articles.author: Michael Dorstewitz
articles.summary: According to new research, the Earth's oceanic currents, including the Gulf Stream, could be near collapse. Scientists have been making wild predictions since at least 1895. The public is cooling on the subject of climate change. A Gallup poll shows that only 2% of American voters consider it a top issue.

articles.title: Climate leaders are talking about 'overshoot' into warming danger zone. Here's what it means
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement sought to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius since preindustrial times. Last year it was 2.3 degrees Celsius. The limit is based on temperatures averaged over a decade. Scientists have said it's inevitable that the limit will be passed.

articles.title: Climate leaders are talking about 'overshoot' into warming danger zone. Here's what it means
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: The 2015 Paris Agreement sought to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) since preindustrial times. Last year, Earth warmed by about 1.3 degrees Celsius. Scientists say it's inevitable that Earth will go beyond that limit in coming years or decades.

articles.title: Climate leaders are talking about 'overshoot' into warming danger zone. Here's what it means
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: The world's climate leaders are conceding that Earth's warming will shoot past a hard limit they set a decade ago. But they're not conceding defeat. They are pinning their hopes on eventually forcing global temperatures back below the red line they set in the 2015 Paris Agreement.

articles.title: Climate leaders are talking about 'overshoot' into warming danger zone. Here's what it means
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: The world's climate leaders are conceding that Earth's warming will shoot past a hard limit they set a decade ago. But they're not conceding defeat. They are pinning their hopes on eventually forcing global temperatures back below the red line they set in the 2015 Paris Agreement.

articles.title: Investing in our best future
articles.summary: Scott Willis is a Dunedin-based Green Party MP. He is concerned about climate change and the future of Aotearoa. He believes we have everything we need to make the transition to a renewable energy system, but the biggest challenge is to build the collective will to take action.

articles.title: How Smart Tech Builds Resilience And Protects Vulnerable Communities
articles.author: Dianne Plummer
articles.summary: Cities are at the frontlines of climate change, digital transformation and rapid population growth. The devastation of Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica, which produced catastrophic flooding and widespread infrastructure failure, underscored how urgently cities must prepare for climate extremes. The Caribbean and small island states know this reality intimately. Island nations contribute less than 0.6 percent of global emissions, yet they face disproportionately severe impacts, including stronger hurricanes, and rising sea levels. Smart governance is the foundation of any resilient city. Smart economy is more adaptive to shock. Smart mobility and infrastructure form the operational backbone of a city's resilience. Smart environment and sustainability are also important.

articles.title: Climate change killed his friend. Now he's seeking justice
articles.author: Juliette Alfano
articles.summary: The effects of climate change are being felt around the world. Ben's friend Rosa was killed in the 2021 flash floods in the Wallonia region in Belgium. Ben hasn't missed a single climate march since. According to estimates, climate inaction is on track to cost the global economy $38 trillion per year in damages within the next 25 years.

articles.title: Northern Norway feels the consequences of record-high fossil fuel emissions
articles.author: Elizaveta Vereykina
articles.summary: Fossil fuel emissions are projected to rise 1.1% in 2025. This is 10% higher than in 2015 when the Paris Agreement was adopted. Global warming will affect winters in northern Norway. To achieve the goal set out in Paris Agreement, the greenhouse gas emissions should be cut by almost 60% by 2035.

articles.title: Continue vigil against salt pan encroachments on rivers: NGT
articles.summary: The Southern Bench of the National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed Tamil Nadu government authorities to maintain constant surveillance over salt pans along Vaippar and Kallar rivers in Vilathikulam area in Thoothukudi district. The Bench found that salt pans had occupied thousands of acres of waterbodies, obstructing natural water flow and exacerbating flooding.

articles.title: Urgent Appeal for Hurricane Melissa Recovery Funds
articles.author: nycaribnews
articles.summary: Melissa made landfall at New Hope in Eastern Westmoreland and devastated the entire Constituency. 26 people died and more than 2000 homes were destroyed. Historic churches, schools, health centers, public offices and police stations have been destroyed. P.J. Patterson spent his entire career in representative politics in that Constituence and adjoining ones in St. James, St. Elizabeth and Hanover.

articles.title: The climate crisis is expensive: net zero is cheaper for Australia than not doing more
articles.author: Nick Evershed
articles.summary: The Liberal and National parties argue that the net zero emissions target by 2050 will cost too much. Ortec Finance modelling shows that it is cheaper for Australia and the world to reach net zero by 2050 than to delay the transition to net zero. Treasury report analysed three different net zero scenarios and concluded that a clear and credible climate action will lead to more jobs, higher wages and better living standards for Australians.

articles.title: Climate Change Could Heat the Earth Right Into a New Ice Age
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: The Earth has gone through some dramatic climate changes in its 4.6-billion-year history. Biological and oceanic feedback loops could outpace the Earth's 'natural thermostat' and lead to a premature deep freeze hundreds of thousands of years in the future. Algal blooms in the ocean could be responsible for this runaway effect.

articles.title: Can the world quit coal?
articles.author: Stacy D. Van Deveer
articles.summary: There is frustration that the world isn't making progress on climate change fast enough. World leaders and thousands of researchers, activists and lobbyists are in Brazil for the 30th annual United Nations climate conference in which they will discuss climate change issues.   .

articles.title: Yellow fever and dengue cases surge in South America as climate crisis fuels health issues
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Disease outbreaks from South America to Europe have been worsened by rising global temperatures, experts say. The disease outbreaks are linked to climate change, they say.   Â. Â  y.  y. Y.  Y.

articles.title: Vietnam's Mekong Delta threatened by rising sea levels
articles.author: Asia
articles.summary: Vietnam's Mekong Delta is under threat from climate change. The region produces half of Vietnam's food supply and is being hit hard by rising sea levels and saltwater intrusion. The landscape is changing and with it, the delicate balance of an entire ecosystem.

articles.title: WHO and Brazil urge swift action on Belém Health Action Plan at COP30
articles.author: World Health Organization
articles.summary: 1 in 12 hospitals worldwide is at risk of climate-related shutdowns due to extreme heat, according to a new special report released today by the World Health Organization (WHO), the Government of Brazil (COP30 Presidency) and the WHO. Over 540 000 people die from extreme heat each year and 1 million die from it every year.

articles.title: Ac/dc Concert Rocks Melbourne, Australia, Ground Trembles up to 3.5 Km Away
articles.summary: An AC/DC concert on Wednesday night (November 12, 2025) caused Melbourne, Australia, to shake, rattle, and roll with low-level seismic vibrations, according to the Australian Broadcast Corporation (ABC). The concert was held in Melbourne's Melbourne Arena.

articles.title: Walcott villagers plea to council to maintain their sea wall
articles.author: Phoebe Ozanne
articles.summary: People living in Walcott in North Norfolk are worried about the future of their homes. North Norfolk District Council is working on a plan to move away from a defensive to an adaptative approach to sea defences. The sea wall was built as a result of the North Sea deadly flood of 1953, which saw a lot of the village lost to the sea.

articles.title: Villagers' desperate plea to stop homes falling into the sea
articles.author: Phoebe Ozanne
articles.summary: People living in Walcott in North Norfolk are worried about the future of their homes. North Norfolk District Council is working on a plan to move away from a defensive to an adaptative approach to sea defences. The sea wall was built as a result of the North Sea deadly flood of 1953, which saw a lot of the village lost to the sea.

articles.title: Climate leaders say breach of warming limit inevitable
articles.summary: World climate leaders acknowledge that global warming will surpass the 1.5 degrees Celsius limit set in the Paris climate agreement, but they remain hopeful that temperatures can be reduced eventually.    .   "I am not worried about the future of the planet, but I am concerned about the present day."

articles.title: Over 1,750 tons of rice provided to Dak Lak people affected by typhoon No. 13
articles.author: SGGPO
articles.summary: Typhoon No. 13 recently hit Dak Lak Province, causing three deaths and 13 injuries. Over 10,500 houses were damaged, with collapsed roofs or structural damage. More than 9,200 homes were flooded, including 188 completely destroyed. Over 280 infrastructure facilities were affected, and 51,720 hectares of crops were damaged.

articles.title: Worsening State of Baltic III Putting Environment and Fisheries at ‘Serious Risk': FFAW
articles.author: Sara Strickland
articles.summary: The Baltic III has sustained further structural damage as a result of harsh weather conditions over the last week. There is a more noticeable buckle in the hull and the bow and stern were moving independently of each other as waves crashed against it. The union met with the ship's owners and salvage officials to urge immediate cleanup before the onset of winter conditions.

articles.title: Scientists Warn Key Ocean Current Collapse Could Bring Ice Age
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Iceland is developing a disaster-preparedness policy for climate change. Scientists warn AMOC collapse could destabilize rainfall for farmers in Africa, India and South America and plunge Northern Europe into colder winters. Britain directs over 81 million pounds into research into AMOC.

articles.title: Belém's Hunger, Poverty Declaration Places World's Most Vulnerable Populations at Centre of Global Climate Policy
articles.author: Joyce Chimbi
articles.summary: Juliana Kerexu Mirim Mariano's father and grandfather were among the first families displaced from their ancestral village in Sundarbans 60 years ago. The Guarani Yvyrupa Commission advocates for the rights of Guarana peoples in southern and southeastern Brazil. Njagga Touray, party representative from Gambia in West Africa, is worried about the food situation in his country.

articles.title: COP30: Experts warn of ‘woefully poor progress' since Paris Agreement
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: COP30 is taking place in Brazil. CO2 emissions from fossil fuel and industrial use have grown by over 7% globally since 2015, according to Alice from the University of California, Santa Barbara. She says the gap between climate action and ambition has never been wider.

articles.title: Reducing impact of climate change requires agricultural adjustments
articles.author: Mike Altshuler
articles.summary: To avoid the worst climate outcomes, we need to deal with our land problem. Agriculture generates one-fourth of all climate-warming emissions. Agriculture is the leading driver of deforestation. We lose a soccer field's worth of tropical forest every six seconds.

articles.title: Renewable Friday: COP30 News
articles.author: Mokurai
articles.summary: LONGi will participate in the climate conference in Belém with presentations on biodiversity, climate action and solar energy projects in Brazil. Albanese government committed Australia to net zero emissions by 2050, with the interim goals of 43% by 2030 and 62-70% by 2035.

articles.title: Rainfall remains average as Tanzania's weather agency sounds alarm on strong winds
articles.author: Mwandishi Wa Habari
articles.summary: The Southern Highlands regional manager of the Tanzania Meteorological Authority, Elius Lipiki, has told The Citizen that the current weather patterns are influenced by elevated sea surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean. The rains are forecast to begin in the second and third weeks of November 2025 and continue until May 2026, potentially causing flooding in homes, rivers, canals, and streams.

articles.title: Survey Shows Nearly All MN Towns Feeling Climate Change Impacts
articles.author: Jim Maurice
articles.summary: 90 percent of local governments say their residents have experienced the impacts of climate-related weather trends over the past year. Climate change impacts include more damaging storms, flooding and poor air quality. 60 percent of the respondents say financial barriers prevent them from taking action and over half need more funding.

articles.title: Battle to host next COP heats up between T�rkiye, Australia
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Diplomats at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil have to choose between drinking flat whites or strong beers next door for their next meal.    - a photo of a flat white is from a Turkish coffee shop. - a picture of a strong beer is from the same place.

articles.title: These areas in Horry County are the top 5 spots to buy a home. Here's why
articles.author: Terri Richardson
articles.summary: There are 21 ZIP codes in Horry County, South Carolina. Niche has ranked the top five ZIP codes as the best places to buy a home in the county. The median home value in Surfside Beach is $278,800 and the median rent is $1,234 a month. In Forestbrook, the median house value is $320,400 and the average rent price is $148.

articles.title: Key Ocean Current Faltering, Raising Risk Of "Ice Age"-Like Cooling
articles.author: Tyler Durden
articles.summary: A new study warns that the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) could collapse before 2100. Warming temperatures are melting Greenland ice sheet, sending freshwater into the North Atlantic and slowing the AMOC. If that happened, Europe could face drastic cooling and drier conditions.

articles.title: Carolina Bays Parkway extension talk continues in North Carolina
articles.summary: Carolina Bays Parkway extension talk continues in North Carolina. NCDOT, SCDOT and FHA are working to extend S.C. 31 from Horry County, South Carolina, to Brunswick County, North Carolina, as part of the project.

articles.title: Groups to PH gov't: Protect Verde Island Passage for climate survival of Filipinos
articles.author: Journal Online
articles.summary: There are themes for oceans and biodiversity at the 30th Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP30) in Brazil. Civil society groups urge the government to protect the Verde Island Passage (VIP) and the health of Philippine seas and coasts. The first environmental disaster that the administration under President Bongbong Marcos encountered was the catastrophic oil spill from the sinking of MT Princess Empress in the VIP. The CESCR recognized the protection of the VIP as a key measure for advancing the country's climate mitigation commitments.

articles.title: 14 Doomsday Predictions That Were Dismissed—Until They Started Coming True
articles.author: Danielle Sachs
articles.summary: There are many doomsday predictions that are coming true. The decline of honeybee populations, the melting of polar ice caps, overfishing and the rise of natural disasters are just a few of them. Water scarcity might have seemed like a distant threat, but it's now a reality for millions around the world.

articles.title: COP30: Indigenous, Women's Role Central in Climate Action
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: George Institute and UNSW academics explain why COP30 must not overlook the power of grassroots and community-based responses to climate change. Women's health is central to climate resilience, and policy needs to be shaped through inclusive, participatory, locally led processes. For Indigenous women, climate, health and gender are understood through relational obligations to Country, kin, community, and to the wellbeing of future generations.

articles.title: UW-Stevens Point seeks public input Nov. 17 on its Climate Action and Resilience Plan
articles.author: Nida Tazeen
articles.summary: The University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point is seeking public input on its Climate Action and Resilience Plan. The plan outlines strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the economic, environmental and social challenges caused by climate change. A public meeting to discuss the plan is set for 5 p.m. Nov. 17 in the Pinery Room at the Portage County Public Library, 1001 Main St.

articles.title: Thousands of acres of farmland on the Treasure Coast may be lost to urban sprawl by 2040
articles.author: Jack Randall
articles.summary: Sprawling development threatens Treasure Coast's rural heartland. Indian River, St. Lucie and Martin counties would lose 3.4%, 7.4% and 2.2% of their farmland by 2040 if sprawl continues at its current pace. American Farmland Trust recommends conservation easements and building compact cities to preserve farmland.

articles.title: Rural Wairarapa communities on climate change frontline
articles.author: Local Democracy Reporter
articles.summary: Rural communities in Wairarapa are at risk from climate change, drought, pests and invasive plants, and increasingly severe weather. The last time the emergency operations centre at Greater Wellington was activated in the Wellington Region was in June 2021 for the Wellington South Coast swells. The Wairsarapa climate is expected to get hotter and drier.

articles.title: Creatives need a Climate Resilience Fund
articles.summary: After Hurricane Melissa, I was in Jakarta, Indonesia, where the Global Creative Economy Council (GCEC) was convening. This region is the third largest in the world behind India and China, with the fifth largest economy and boasting a gross domestic product (GDP) of US$3.8 trillion in 2023. ASEAN is significant for its trade in creative goods at an annual growth rate of 11 per cent and its creative industries account for 7.1 per cent of GDP, with 3.2 billion in creative services and employing 7.2 million individuals.

articles.title: Trapped in the hills
articles.summary: Hagley Gap in western St Thomas was badly affected by Hurricane Melissa. The Mahogany Vale Bridge, which connects Hagley Gap to Mavis Bank is impassable due to heavy rain. It's a four-hour journey to get to and from the community. It costs a lot of money to get out of the community and the shops are running low on supplies.

articles.title: Beyond empty promises: Why Africa needs real adaptation finance
articles.author: Saada Mohamed
articles.summary: Paris Agreement was one of the biggest successes and turning points for the multilateral climate process. On the 10th anniversary of the agreement, minimal progress on adaptation measures has been made. Developed countries delivered US$26 billion in adaptation finance in 2023, a decline from 2022 levels, due to reduced funding from multilateral development banks. The UNEP report warns that developed countries will likely miss the doubling pledge by 2025. Finance for adaptation is shrinking amid wars, debt distress among developing countries, and shifting geopolitical priorities.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock Florida, the Southeast
articles.author: HANNAH FINGERHUT
articles.summary: 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. The direct shot of Arctic air migrated east from the Northern Plains. The southeastern U.S. will face a few more colder-than-normal days before warming up later in the week.

articles.title: Rann: Gas Lobby Uses Tobacco Tactics for Tax Breaks
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Mike Rann AC delivered the second annual Dr Hugh Saddler Memorial Lecture at the State Library of South Australia last night. He slammed the fossil fuel lobby's grip on climate policy in the country. He compared it to the tobacco industry tactics of the past. He is appalled that multinational gas companies are making huge profits from exporting Australian resources while paying little or no tax.

articles.title: National Takes NZ Backwards On Climate Change
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Climate change is a global challenge that demands real action here at home. National's are calling for action on climate change here at the home, in Australia and in the UK. National’s are calling on the government to do more to tackle climate change.

articles.title: 14 Cool Facts About the Ice Age
articles.author: Vuk Jovanovic
articles.summary: There have been at least five Ice Ages in Earth's 4.5 billion-year history, each lasting millions of years. The most recent Ice Age began 2.6 million years ago and continues today as Earth is in an interglacial period. The Sahara Desert was a lush grassland teeming with lakes, rivers and diverse plant and animal life during the Ice Age.

articles.title: Haitian, Ethiopian Climate Voices at COP30
articles.author: Felipe de
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, Brazil, the UN International Organization for Migration is pressing negotiators to make climate mobility a core part of adaptation plans. Robert Montinard from Haiti fled to Brazil as a refugee after the 2010 earthquake. Makebib Tadesse from Ethiopia is part of the UN refugee agency's delegation at COP30.

articles.title: 14 Unsettling Climate Predictions Keeping Scientists Up At Night
articles.summary: Climate change is not just a topic of scientific debate, it's a reality unfolding around us. According to IPCC, sea levels could rise by as much as 1 meter by 2100 if current emission trends continue. Heatwaves are becoming more intense and frequent, affecting everything from energy usage to public health. Unpredictable weather patterns can devastate agriculture, leading to crop failures and food shortages. The polar ice caps are melting at alarming rates, contributing to rising sea levels and altering oceanic currents.

articles.title: Climate Talk Series Q&A: UGA's Marshall Shepherd highlights evidence of climate change
articles.author: Erica Van Buren
articles.summary: Dr. Marshall Shepherd is the director of the Department of Geography and Atmospheric Sciences at the University of Georgia. He believes that climate change is real and that it's caused by human activity. The most conclusive evidence is in the heatwaves, intense rainstorms, and drought conditions.

articles.title: Researchers unearth 777,000-year-old discovery on remote Arctic island: 'I was not expecting that at all'
articles.author: Susan Elizabeth Turek
articles.summary: Researchers unearth 777,000-year-old discovery on remote Arctic island. They found the remnants of a glacier that could be more than one million years old. The team believes the glacier could give them insight into the early Pleistocene epoch. Human activities have caused the planet to overheat at an accelerated rate.

articles.title: Commentary: The time for comfort is over — Climate change won't wait till we're ready
articles.author: Natalia Arcos Cano
articles.summary: Melissa is the strongest storm ever recorded in the Atlantic basin, fueled by unseasonably warm ocean temperatures 2.5 °F above average. Seven of the nine planetary boundaries essential for sustaining life on Earth are in decline, with ocean acidification newly entering the list of concerns.

articles.title: Report: Global carbon emissions from fossil fuels are set to hit a record high in 2025
articles.author: nafiseh yazdani
articles.summary: Global carbon emissions from fossil fuels are set to hit a record high this year, according to the latest Global Carbon Budget report. Fossil fuel emissions will increase by 1.1%, reaching 38.1 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide this year. At this pace, the world could cross the 1.5C-degree warming limit within four years.

articles.title: Thoothukudi Fishermen Advised Against Venturing Into Sea
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: Authorities have issued a weather warning for the coastal district of Thoothukudi, advising fishermen to avoid venturing into the sea until further notice due to the likelihood of strong winds and rough sea conditions. Fishermen who have already set out to sea have been urged to return to the shore immediately. The current wind pattern is expected to persist over the next 24 to 48 hours.

articles.title: Takeaway from Cop30: climate action needs to be up close and local
articles.author: David Dodwell
articles.summary: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva is watching the Cop30 UN climate summit in Belem on the edge of Brazil's Amazon forests. Lula and Cop30 president Andre Correa do Lago are calling for a mutirao: community mobilisation. They are pushing for delegates to move from negotiation to implementation.

articles.title: Koala Count Kicks Off In SA
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: This year's Great Koala Count in South Australia is being conducted between November 15-23. Citizen scientists and residents in the Adelaide Hills, Mount Lofty Ranges, Fleurieu Peninsula, Kangaroo Island, South-East, Riverland and Eyre Peninsula will help collect the latest numbers. Professor Karen Burke da Silva at Flinders University is encouraging the public to download the Koala Spotter mobile phone app and record sightings around the state.

articles.title: Climate Change: 10 Charts Reveal a Warming World (2025)
articles.summary: September 2023 was nearly 2°C warmer than September 1956. Wealthy nations have contributed the vast majority of greenhouse gases to date. Asia and Africa are experiencing a surge in emissions. Deforestation is releasing stored carbon back into the atmosphere. Sea levels have risen nearly 25 cm in the last 140 years.

articles.title: After the Blaze: Galicia's Struggle with Ash and Contaminated Waters
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The aftermath of the devastating wildfires that swept through Spain and Portugal continues to impact communities, particularly in Spain's northwestern Galicia region. Residents are now grappling with water contamination as autumn rains bring ash and sediment into the waterways, rendering drinking water unsafe. The fires devastated homes, agriculture, and livestock, with losses exceeding 600 million euros.

articles.title: Ambassador Ruleta Camacho-Thomas stands up for DSSS at Belém side event
articles.author: A Hover
articles.summary: Antigua and Barbuda's Ambassador for Climate Change Ruleta Camacho-Thomas has stressed the call for systemic financial reform at COP30 in Brazil. Small Island Developing States contribute less than one percent of global emissions yet remain among the world's most climate-vulnerable nations. Many of them are in or near debt distress, with many spending more on debt servicing than on health, education, or adaptation.

articles.title: China and Saudi Arabia among nations receiving climate loans, analysis reveals
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Investigation by Guardian and Carbon Brief finds just a fifth of funds to fight global heating went to the poorest 44 countries, according to the report.       - Carbon Brief, Guardian and Guardian's investigation found that only 5% of funds for global heating were given to poor countries.

articles.title: Dennis C. Miller: Empathy
articles.author: Dennis C. Miller: Empathy
articles.summary: Quail, doves, pigeons, blackbirds and sparrows shared bread and cracker crumbs in my backyard this morning. They showed no fear, despair, greed or violence. Humans killed over 100 million people in the 20th century in what we call war.

articles.title: First snowfall brings excitement to Santa Claus Village in Lapland
articles.author: euronews
articles.summary: Lapland has finally seen its first snowfall of the coming winter. It follows the third-warmest September on record, followed by the warmest October on record. Average temperatures were 1.9 degrees Celsius higher than they would have been without climate change.

articles.title: Uwan leaves P222-M agri losses in Pampanga
articles.author: Sun Star
articles.summary: The Provincial Government of Pampanga reported P222 million agricultural losses due to Super Typhoon 'Uwan' on Friday. Rice crops sustained damages totaling P220 million, according to the Provincial Agriculturist's Office (OPA).   .

articles.title: Reducing chemical nitrogen use identified as an 'action' to fight climate change
articles.author: Francess Mcdonnell
articles.summary: The government is set to release details of the "actions" it wants the agriculture, forestry and seafood sectors to take as part of a national effort to tackle climate change. The government has approved 13 Sectoral Adaptation Plans (SAPs) which aim "to support resilience, competitiveness and economic growth in the face of severe climate change impacts".

articles.title: Tamil Nadu: Fishermen advised against venturing into sea at Thoothukudi
articles.author: ANI
articles.summary: There is a weather warning for the coastal district of Thoothukudi in Tamil Nadu. Fishermen are advised to stay away from the sea until further notice. Rescue teams and disaster response units are on standby in case the weather worsens. The current wind pattern is expected to persist over the next 24 to 48 hours.

articles.title: AGRA Urges a ‘Farmer-First' Climate Breakthrough as COP30 Opens in Brazil
articles.author: Belém
articles.summary: Malawi is at the UN Climate Conference (COP30) in Belém, Brazil. The conference is expected to focus on turning climate pledges into concrete results. Malawi is still reeling from the effects of Cyclone Freddy and erratic rainfall patterns. AGRA is calling for targeted investment in soil rehabilitation, diversified cropping, and data systems to guide national agricultural planning.

articles.title: OAIC Makes Case For Climate Change Adaptation, Sustainability
articles.author: New Telegraph
articles.summary: The Organisation of African Instituted Churches (OAIC) Nigeria Region has urged a shift from awareness of climate change to practical adaptation and climate-resistant practices. The workshop took place in the Ughelli and Asaba areas. Government officials, traditional rulers, agricultural extension officers, scientists, smallholder farmers, development partners and christian leaders from Delta and Akwa Ibom participated. OAIC International, with Rev. Daniel Okoh as its International President, supported the workshop.

articles.title: Cork man pleads for help amid fears his house will be flooded in heavy rains
articles.author: Martin Mongan
articles.summary: Millstreet resident calls on Cork County Council to future-proof houses from flooding. He wants council to do this to prevent future-problems like flooding in Millstreet.      Â   .   in the future-protective houses.

articles.title: World on track to breach 1.5C climate threshold within four years
articles.author: Elif Şanlı
articles.summary: Global Carbon Budget report shows a regional divergence in emissions trends. The United States and European Union are experiencing an acceleration in emissions growth, while China and India are seeing a notable slowdown. The report also documents that over 35 nations have successfully reduced their emissions over the past decade while maintaining economic growth.

articles.title: Stay in the Paris Agreement with this one weird trick
articles.author: Ryan Cropp
articles.summary: The conservative parties are expected to agree on a new policy position on Sunday. It would abandon the goal of achieving net zero carbon emissions. The Liberal Party has declared that it would remain a signatory to the Paris Agreement, which aims to limit global average temperature increases to 'well below 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels' by the end of the century.

articles.title: With Trump absent from COP30 talks, the world moves on without U.S.
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: The world is committing to climate action with or without the United States, as scientists sound the alarm and the world is taking steps to combat climate change.       .   "With or without U.S."   for the world to take action.

articles.title: World set to surpass UN climate goals within 4 years, new report warns
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Global carbon emissions from fossil fuels are set to hit a record high this year. Rises in the US and EU are accelerating, but they are slowing in China and India. At this pace, the world could cross the 1.5C-degree warming limit within four years.

articles.title: Global CO₂ Emissions Hit Record High in 2025 as Fossil Fuel Use Continues to Rise
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: The 2025 Global Carbon Budget reports a new record for fossil fuel CO₂ emissions. The report warns that the remaining carbon budget, the total amount of CO ₂ that can still be emitted if we are to limit global warming to 1.5°C, is nearly used up. Climate change is intensifying the problem.

articles.title: Four years of no climate progress, Climate Tracker sounds alarm
articles.summary: Climate Action Tracker tracks more than 40 countries responsible for over 82 percent of global emissions. It shows the Paris Agreement has delivered progress in slowing global warming. However, for four years, countries have failed to strengthen their 2030 climate targets. The projected temperature remains unchanged at 2.6 degrees.

articles.title: Denbighshire: Bird keepers urged to take action on bird flu
articles.author: Josh Price
articles.summary: Denbighshire County Council has issued a warning to owners of poultry and game birds about the ongoing risk of avian influenza. The risk of the disease rises during the winter months due to the migration of waterfowl and gulls, which can carry and spread the virus. New legal requirements came into force on Thursday, November 13. Keepers with 50 or more birds are required to house them to reduce the risk of infection.

articles.title: UNESCO Rallies Aid for Caribbean Post-Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Audrey Azoulay announced emergency support for Jamaica, Cuba and Haiti after Hurricane Melissa struck the Caribbean on October 28. The aid is intended to sustain educational continuity, assess damage to cultural heritage and strengthen the reliability of information. UNESCO has already committed $300,000 in funds.

articles.title: Okumu Modachi And Phares Mutembei
articles.author: Standard Group Plc
articles.summary: The urgency of the climate crisis is being felt more acutely in climate-vulnerable countries like Kenya. Global leaders are preparing for the COP29 summit, which will take place in COP29 in Nairobi, Kenya on November 29th and 30th.

articles.title: South Korean Farmers Sue Over Climate Impact: A Battle Against Power Giants
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: South Korean farmer Hwang Seong-yeol is challenging the Korea Electric Power Corporation (KEPCO) in a lawsuit unprecedented in South Korea. They claim KEPCO's reliance on fossil fuels has amplified climate change, directly impacting their agricultural output. Experts argue that the country's sluggish transition to renewable energy could hinder technological advancements and impact economic stability.

articles.title: From country to coast, this podcast maps climate action at work
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: From country to coast, this podcast maps climate action at work. The Guardian reports that it's a podcast called "The Guardian's Climate Change Podcast" which is available on iTunes and on The Guardian's podcast website. It's available in English and in Spanish.

articles.title: Global CO2 emissions to hit record high in 2025, report warns
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Global carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels are set to hit a record high in 2025. With CO2 emissions still increasing, keeping global warming below 1.5 degrees Celsius is no longer plausible, according to the study highlighted Thursday at the 30th United Nations Climate.

articles.title: Over 900k displaced Gazans at risk of flooding as severe storm approaches
articles.author: Bernama
articles.summary: 900,000 displaced civilians are at risk of flooding in southern Gaza as a severe weather system approaches. The approaching storm is dangerous and threatens to flood thousands of tents along the coastline and damage large areas inside the city, according to Anadolu Ajansi.

articles.title: Lake County residents share their concerns during flood assessment
articles.author: Brandon Spencer
articles.summary: Lake County Office of Emergency Management held a countywide hazard vulnerability assessment Thursday. The assessment is intended to address local and regional infrastructure areas that are prone to flooding hazards over the next 50 years. Valier Hunt lives in the Joanna Shores Subdivision of Eustis. Her home was spared from flooding, but her neighbor's home was ruined.

articles.title: 35 philanthropies vow $300mn to help tackle impact of climate crisis
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: The Climate and Health Funders Coalition has committed an initial $300 million for tackling climate change and its impact on health through extreme heat, air pollution and spread of diseases like malaria and dengue. The Coalition is made up of 35 leading philanthropies.

articles.title: Australia and Turkey at loggerheads over 2026 climate summit
articles.author: Jennifer A. Dlouhy
articles.summary: Australia and Turkey are vying to host the annual United Nations climate summit next year. Advocates supporting Australia's bid mounted a news conference outside Turkey's pavilion at COP30. First Nations Australians performed a cultural dance in the Turkish pavilion as workers in the pavilion began handing out coffee and tea.

articles.title: CARICOM appoints Ministerial Leads for COP30 to strengthen regional climate action
articles.author: Joanne Clark
articles.summary: Caribbean Community (CARICOM) has named new Ministerial Leads to represent the region at the 30th Meeting of the Conference of Parties (COP30) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change in Belém, Brazil. The appointments aim to reinforce CARICOM's unified stance on climate justice and resilience.

articles.title: England at risk of drought next year, Environment Agency warns
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: The Environment Agency has warned that England faces widespread drought next year without a wet winter. Yorkshire and the Midlands are already in drought and other areas are experiencing 'exceptionally dry conditions'. England has received only 83 per cent of its average rainfall from January to October, enduring its driest spring in 132 years and the hottest summer on record.

articles.title: Hear Indigenous Voices
articles.author: Post News Network
articles.summary: Eileen Mairena Cunningham is an indigenous woman from the Awala Kupia Territory on Nicaragua's Caribbean coast. She is a member of the Global Caucus of Indigenous Peoples on Climate Change, which has developed positions on the main themes of this year's UN Climate Change Conference (COP30) in Belém.

articles.title: Darwin's top earning spots post Y2K
articles.author: Courtney Snowden
articles.summary: Darwin property prices have increased up to nine-fold so far this millennium. The best performing suburbs are Gunn, Rosebery, Durack, Humpty Doo and Virginia. Brisbane had the best performing suburb over the past 30 years with home prices in New Beith 18 times higher to a median of $1.268m.

articles.title: Ley pledges to cut emissions despite scrapping net zero
articles.author: Andrew Brown
articles.summary: "Emission targets are not just a set and forget, because we should look at what the reality is on the ground and how much of that reality is changing," says the minister. "It's in the interest of Australian families and communities to look at the reality and change the targets."

articles.title: Russian Embassy loses its land, its cool and all sense of irony
articles.author: Tony Wright
articles.summary: The High Court of Australia ruled this week that Albanese government was within its legal rights when it revoked the lease on a prime block of Canberra land on which the Russian Federation wanted to build a new embassy. The block, site of a post-Cold War saga stretching back 27 years, sits virtually across the road from Parliament House.

articles.title: Russian Embassy loses its land, its cool and all sense of irony
articles.author: Tony Wright
articles.summary: The Russians are unhappy that Australia has stolen back their land near Lake Burley Griffin in Canberra. A small group of pro-Putin protesters gathered outside the prime minister's house at Kirribilli in June 2023 to demand he allow Russia to retain its proposed embassy site.

articles.title: Six-million-year-old Antarctic ice offers rare glimpse into Earth's past
articles.author: New Atlas
articles.summary: Antarctica's ice cores are like frozen diaries of Earth's past, preserving ancient air and climate clues. Most continuous records go back about 800,000 years, but in the Allan Hills, a special patch of blue ice holds snapshots dating back as far as 2.7 million years.

articles.title: Over 4.5M Afghans Return Home, Overwhelming Fragile Nation
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Afghanistan's population has increased by 10% since more than 4.5 million returned. The returnees and host communities are under immense strain. Afghanistan faces recurrent climate shocks including droughts and floods. Taliban restrictions on women and girls persist and recent quakes killed more than 2,200 and 27 people.

articles.title: Winters are getting warmer
articles.summary: Springfield's average winter temperature has risen by 5.3 degrees since 1970. Winters have warmed by 3.9 degrees in 244 U.S. cities from 1970 to 2025. Warmer winters affect snowfall, water supplies, and even ripple into spring allergies and summer fruits.

articles.title: New Book by David L. Hawk Connects Climate Change, Human Behavior, and the Power of Community
articles.author: Get News
articles.summary: David L. Hawk's new book, The Climate is Changing, Can Humans? is a thought-provoking look at the changing climate and society's role in the climate change. It offers a fresh, human-centered perspective in a time of intensifying climate disruption.

articles.title: World set to surpass UN climate goals within 4 years, new report warns
articles.author: Anadolu Staff
articles.summary: Global carbon emissions from fossil fuels are set to hit a record high this year, according to a recent report. The report estimates that fossil fuel emissions will increase by 1.1%, reaching 38.1 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide this year. At this pace, the world could cross the 1.5C-degree warming limit within four years.

articles.title: ‘Green' energy transition leaves a dirty trail in the Philippines' nickel belt
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: Nickel mining in the Philippines' Caraga region is driving deforestation and pollution, according to a recent report. Climate Rights International (CRI) is the U.S.-based NGO behind the report. CRI is based in Manila, the mining capital of the Philippines.

articles.title: Australia and Turkey at loggerheads over 2026 climate summit
articles.author: The Daily Item
articles.summary: Australia and Turkey are vying to host the annual United Nations climate summit next year. The contest broke into view at the current climate talks in Brazil on Thursday. The winner will be announced on December 11th in Rio de Janeiro. The current talks are taking place in Brazil.

articles.title: AUC Professor Leads Global Academic Discussion on Climate and Urban Governance in Developing Countries
articles.author: Al Bawaba
articles.summary: New research papers co-edited by Professor Shahjahan Bhuiyan, associate professor and associate dean for the University of Illinois at Chicago are co-authored by him and co-editors. They focus on the growing risks from climate change in developing countries.

articles.title: From Atmosphere to Attitude: 'The Climate Is Changing, Can Humans?' Challenges Readers to Change
articles.author: Get News
articles.summary: David L. Hawk's new book, The Climate is Changing, Can Humans Can Change It? argues that the real emergency isn't just in our skies and oceans, but in our habits, our culture, and our willingness to change at all, according to the author.

articles.title: Strengthening infrastructure critical as Fiji faces rising climate challenges
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Climate change is a major challenge for the people of Fiji. It affects their lives, wellbeing, and the economy. Lead.       in the video below. For more information, go to: http://www.cnn.com/video/fiji-climate-change.

articles.title: Vietnam's Mekong Delta threatened by rising sea levels
articles.author: France24
articles.summary: Vietnam's Mekong Delta is under serious threat from climate change. The agricultural region produces half of the country's food supply and it's under threat from the climate change, according to the UN.   Â. Â   y

articles.title: Climate leaders warn of ‘overshoot' into warming danger zone
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: After years of pushing the world to limit Earth's warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, climate leaders are starting to acknowledge that the target set by the 2015 Paris Agreement will almost surely be breached. They are hopeful that temperatures can be brought back though.

articles.title: Early Climate Models Got Global Warming Right But Now US Funding Cuts Threaten The Future ...
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Since the 1960s, scientists have been developing and honing models to understand how the earth's climate is changing. These models help predict the phenomena that affect the climate.       The Conversation has published this article on The Conversation.  The article is based on the.

articles.title: Gaza braces as storm looms over 900,000 displaced Palestinians
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Southern Gaza is bracing for another blow to its already battered population. A powerful storm system is heading toward the coastline and threatens to swamp makeshift camps sheltering the homeless.       .   and it is expected to hit the coast within hours.

articles.title: WHO and Brazil urge swift action on Belém Health Action Plan at COP30 (WHO - World Health Organization)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: 1 in 12 hospitals worldwide are at risk of climate-related shutdowns due to extreme heat, according to a new special report released today by the World Health Organization (WHO), the Government of Brazil (COP30) and the WHO. Over 540 000 people die from extreme heat each year and over 1 million die from it every year.

articles.title: Concerns over Kent mega solar farms
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Huge swathes of Romney Marsh will be lost if the proposals go ahead, claims countryside charity.    - The Nature Conservancy. It is concerned about the loss of the Romney Marsh area if the plans go ahead. It's also worried about the impact on the environment.

articles.title: From Haiti To Ethiopia: Voices Of Climate Displacement At COP30
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Floods, heatwaves, droughts and storms are forcing millions from their homes every year. Experts warn that in the not-so-distant future, entire nations could disappear beneath rising seas or become uninhabitable through drought, as a result of climate change.

articles.title: COP30: 10 visuals to help you understand climate change
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: The UN climate conference is underway in Belem, Brazil. Here are key facts that explain how rising temperatures are disrupting our planet today and why the conference is taking place there.    .      i   for confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: COP30: Climate crisis is a health crisis, WHO warns as philanthropies pledge $300m for solutions
articles.author: United Nations
articles.summary: Climate change is already fueling a global health emergency, killing more than half a million people each year through extreme heat and threatening hospitals worldwide, according to a major report released on Friday at COP30 in Bela Horizonte, Brazil, and is threatening to kill more people.

articles.title: Climate Change Minister Heads To COP30
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: 'New Zealand needs all countries to take meaningful climate action in line with rules we all agree to. This is critical for the economy and the Pacific region.    Mr Watts is a member of New Zealand's Climate Action Group (CAG) and a former member of CAG.

articles.title: In hurricane-torn Jamaica, this couple's climate-resilient breadfruit program offers food and hope
articles.author: Redlands Daily Facts
articles.summary: After Hurricane Melissa subsided, the roots of breadfruit trees clung deep into the fertile Jamaican soil. For the past 16 years, Mary and Mike McLaughlin, Jamaican natives who now live in Winnetka, have helped plant almost half a half a billion breadfruit.

articles.title: Cambridge Applauds State Effort to Help Communities Manage Coastal Flooding (City of Cambridge, MA)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Governor Maura Healey's administration has launched a new effort to safeguard the Commonwealth's most vulnerable areas: the coastline. The comprehensive strategy - called the ResilientCoasts Plan - lays out an equity-focused path to protect the coastlines.

articles.title: Climate change killed his friend. Now he's seeking justice
articles.author: France24
articles.summary: The effects of climate change are being felt around the world. Extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and intense. According to recent estimates, climate inaction is on track to cause more extreme weather events in the future, especially due to climate change-caused climate change.

articles.title: Winter hosepipe bans on the cards as England faces drought
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: Water minister warns prolonged dry weather poses risk to farming and the environment, especially to the environment and to the water supply of the country's water supplies.      Â   y  y   Y   e   i

articles.title: Commentary: The time for comfort is over -- Climate change won't wait till we're ready
articles.author: Natalia Arcos Cano
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is the strongest storm ever recorded in the Atlantic basin. Seven of the nine planetary boundaries essential for sustaining life on Earth are in decline. In the U.S., the Energy Department has banned the term 'climate change' from official communications, and the national parks have begun to be stripped of any information regarding climate change. New York City hosted Climate Week, coinciding with the UN General Assembly. Human suffering and pollution are intrinsically tied. The future will be uncomfortable. There is no 'magic solution' left.
